summary.p: The Kantapurāṇam is one of the major Tamil texts about the god Skanda/Murukaṉ. It is the work of Kacciyappa Civācāriyār (14th century?).

The text is incomplete. The manuscript contains: Pāyiram, Uṟpattikkāṇṭam, Acurakāṇṭam (up to Tikkuvicayap Paṭalam, verse 66, itself incomplete) in U3; Makēntirakāṇṭam, Viravāku Kantamātaṉañ Cel Paṭalam (up to verse 8, itself incomplete) in U4. Note that the Tikkuvicayap Paṭalam is not named as such in the manuscript, but is divided into 3 chapters: Kupēraceyap Paṭalam (U3, f161r, lm), Akkiṉiceyap Paṭalam (U3, f163r, lm), Yamaṉ Ceyap Paṭalam (U3, f164r, lm).

binding.p: Original bamboo woodcovers. The number "2" is engraved in the middle of the front woodcover.

origin.origDate: No internal date. Before 1855, as it is part of Ariel’s bequest made in that year to the Société Asiatique, Paris (Rosny 1869).

encodingDesc.p: Abbreviations. c = column, f = folio, lm = left margin, r = recto, rm = right margin, U = unit (codicological and/or textual), v = verso. GOML = Government Oriental Manuscripts Library, Madras/Chennai. MTL = Madras Tamil Lexicon. TMSSML = Tanjore Maharaja Serfoji Sarasvati Mahal Library.

Transliteration conventions. Unmarked puḷḷi, ō, and ē restored. Conjectural (whether the text is not clearly legible or the character is ambigous, e.g. kāl or length of o and e) readings between parentheses. Alternative readings between parentheses separated by slash. Lost or entirely illegible character: "?". Crossed-out character: "X". Conjectural restoration of lost or entirely illegible between square brackets. Uppercase for initial vowels (in excerpts only). Unquoted text represented by (...). Conjunct letter: e.g. t°, to be read tum or tam. Grantha letters in bold. Symbols/Abbreviations made explicit, between curly brackets: = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, short form; = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, long form, that is, with long horizontal stroke towards right; {varuṣam}, {mācam}, {tēti}; {line-filler}. Unfoliated folio number between square brackets, e.g. "f[1]r". Numerals normalised to decimal notation, e.g. "1121" not "1000 1 100 2 10 1". Hyphen occasionaly used to mark in-word components. Hyphen systematically used at the end of a line when the line-beginning is within a word or within a cīr. Sandhi split to the minimum: overshort u occasionally restored as an apostrophe. Stanzas split by cīr, as far as possible. aṭi boundary marked by "‡".
